conclusion: The problem involves understanding how shadows labeled A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves downward.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area behind it. Their position and size depend on the position of the light source and the object.
If the light source moves downward, it gets closer to the objects, causing shadows to become longer due to the lower angle of light.
When the light source is low, shadows become longer, similar to how shadows behave when the sun is low in the sky.
Shadow A is cast by an ice cream glass.
If the light source moves downward, shadow A will extend further away from the glass, making it longer, and its position might shift away from the light source's new position.
Shadow B is cast by a typewriter.
If the light source moves downward, shadow B will become longer and its position might shift accordingly.
Shadow C is cast by a round object, possibly a ball or spherical object.
If the light source moves downward, shadow C might not change in size as much as the others due to its round shape, but it will still become longer.
Shadow D is cast by an object resembling a cone or something with a pointed top.
If the light source moves downward, shadow D will become longer.
The direction of the shadows will become more horizontal as the light source moves downward, stretching the shadows away from the light source.
If the light source is directly above the objects, shadows are directly below them. As the light source moves downward, shadows will stretch out more horizontally.
